text:
Follow-up question for writers: Would you prefer the more general items in a style guide, or repeated in every brief?

Many of these things (e.g. examples of content the brand likes, consistent CTAs, blogs you should link back to) I am tempted to put in a style guide rather than in the brief itself.

text: What is your favorite app/widget for time zones and planning meetings in different time zones globally? Looking to make scheduling meetings with coworkers easier and more aware of what time it is where folks are. :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I add an extra time zone to my Google Cal view! I’m on the east coast and the large majority of my clients are West coast, so having those times side by side is super helpful! You can add a second time zone in settings if you use Google Cal—I think you can also add a world clock too

text:
As a freelancer copywriter looking to close a potential client for Facebook Ad Copy, How do you you folks think I can create a high-value offer in my proposal rather than just "writing copy?"

My potential client is a DTC Ecomm startup and Facebook ads are really valuable to them. This isn't speculation. It's what they have told me.


Any suggestions would be appreciated & thank you in advance! :sweat_smile:

elements.text:
As a freelancer copywriter looking to close a potential client for Facebook Ad Copy, How do you you folks think I can create a high-value offer in my proposal rather than just "writing copy?"

My potential client is a DTC Ecomm startup and Facebook ads are really valuable to them. This isn't speculation. It's what they have told me.


Any suggestions would be appreciated & thank you in advance!

text: Plus, any tips on retainer pricing would be like a cherry on top! :pray::skin-tone-2::cherries:

elements.text: Plus, any tips on retainer pricing would be like a cherry on top!

text: Highly, highly recommend reading $100M Offers by Alex Hormozi. It’s short, costs one dollar, and an incredible resource. (Sorry if this one’s already been mentioned, new to the channel)

elements.text: Highly, highly recommend reading $100M Offers by Alex Hormozi. It’s short, costs one dollar, and an incredible resource. (Sorry if this one’s already been mentioned, new to the channel)

text: Hey everyone! I would love to know if y'all have any tips on creating healthier habits around working with international clients. I've been picking up more clients based in Europe, and I love working with them, but it can mess with my sleeping patterns trying to have more time to chat with them vs. just the end of their day. I've tried scheduling emails and that works a bit but I know there are probably different strategies to make work/life balance easier when working in different time zones.

elements.text: Hey everyone! I would love to know if y'all have any tips on creating healthier habits around working with international clients. I've been picking up more clients based in Europe, and I love working with them, but it can mess with my sleeping patterns trying to have more time to chat with them vs. just the end of their day. I've tried scheduling emails and that works a bit but I know there are probably different strategies to make work/life balance easier when working in different time zones.

text: Great tips - thank you <@UN227ML2H>!

text:
Random best practice question: When you get a brief in a Google doc, do you write your draft within that doc? Or do you create a separate doc for drafting?

I've always done a separate doc because the process can get messy :slightly_smiling_face: but I don't actually know what standard practice is.

elements.text:
Random best practice question: When you get a brief in a Google doc, do you write your draft within that doc? Or do you create a separate doc for drafting?

I've always done a separate doc because the process can get messy
but I don't actually know what standard practice is.

text: Check dm

elements.text: Check dm

text: I always create a separate doc for drafts and then paste my final work on the brief doc.

elements.text: I always create a separate doc for drafts and then paste my final work on the brief doc.

text: I use Figure it Out. It's a browser extension that lets me check other people's timezones against my own

elements.text: I use Figure it Out. It's a browser extension that lets me check other people's timezones against my own

text: Always separate. I don't like to be watched while working. And the chasm between  first and final draft is embarrassingly large for me

elements.text: Always separate. I don't like to be watched while working. And the chasm between  first and final draft is embarrassingly large for me

text: Separate is my preference as a hiring manager and that's what I do whenever I freelance also.

elements.text: Separate is my preference as a hiring manager and that's what I do whenever I freelance also.

text:
Hello freelancers:wave:

I am a content writer for iGaming brands right now. Sometimes, I also write for eCommerce brands. I mainly help brands with their long form content needs (blogs and newsletters to be more specific).

One of the things I plan on doing this year is to branch out my services into another niche. The niche I am looking at right now is B2B SaaS. Now, I have written 1-2 articles in this niche, but I want to build a bigger and better portfolio.

My question is: What is your best advice for someone building a portfolio in the B2B SaaS niche? How does guest-posting work here? Is there a concept of pitching in this niche?

Any input would be highly appreciated! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hello freelancers

I am a content writer for iGaming brands right now. Sometimes, I also write for eCommerce brands. I mainly help brands with their long form content needs (blogs and newsletters to be more specific).

One of the things I plan on doing this year is to branch out my services into another niche. The niche I am looking at right now is B2B SaaS. Now, I have written 1-2 articles in this niche, but I want to build a bigger and better portfolio.

My question is: What is your best advice for someone building a portfolio in the B2B SaaS niche? How does guest-posting work here? Is there a concept of pitching in this niche?

Any input would be highly appreciated!

text: I always create a separate doc and submit the separate doc only. Never been a problem for me. If the client wants it in the same doc they usually ask me to do the same.

elements.text: I always create a separate doc and submit the separate doc only. Never been a problem for me. If the client wants it in the same doc they usually ask me to do the same.

text: My best advice would be to catch up weekly or maybe twice a week at a time which suits both you and your client. This way you don't have to work beyond your preferred hours every day and the communication remains clear too. Of course, convey to your clients that you're facing such a problem.

elements.text: My best advice would be to catch up weekly or maybe twice a week at a time which suits both you and your client. This way you don't have to work beyond your preferred hours every day and the communication remains clear too. Of course, convey to your clients that you're facing such a problem.

text: Thank you! I'll check it out :raised_hands::skin-tone-2:

elements.text: Thank you! I'll check it out
